Lineus longissimus is a species of marine ribbon worm, also known as the bootlace worm or long ribbon worm, belonging to the phylum Nemertea. It is characterized by its extraordinary length, which can reach up to 55 meters (180 feet), making it one of the longest known animals on Earth.

The body of Lineus longissimus is flattened and ribbon-like, with a cylindrical, unsegmented structure. It has a small, sucker-like head and a simple nervous system. The worm's coloration can vary from pale yellow to dark brown or reddish-brown, often with a darker head region.

Lineus longissimus is found in the cold, temperate waters of the northern Atlantic Ocean, primarily along the coasts of Europe and Scandinavia. It typically inhabits rocky or sandy seafloors, where it can burrow into the substrate or hide in crevices and under rocks.

As a predatory nemertean, Lineus longissimus uses its evertible proboscis, which is equipped with specialized cells called nematocysts, to capture and consume small invertebrates, such as crustaceans and mollusks. The worm's remarkable length and flexibility allow it to ambush and ensnare its prey effectively.

Reproduction in Lineus longissimus involves the release of sperm and eggs into the water column, where external fertilization occurs. The resulting larvae undergo a planktonic larval stage before settling and metamorphosing into the adult form.

The exceptional length and elusive nature of Lineus longissimus have made it a subject of fascination for scientists and the general public alike, contributing to the worm's status as one of the most remarkable examples of the diversity and adaptations found in the marine environment.
